Let X be a topological space and A, B be two subsets of X. Prove that the closure of the union of A and B is a subset of the union of the closures of A and B, i.e.,

𝑥 ∈ 𝑥̅∪𝑦̅ where 𝑥∈(𝐴∪𝐵) and 𝑥̅ denotes the closure of 𝑥 in X

if and only if there exists an open set U containing 𝑥 such that

𝑈∩(𝐴∪𝐵) ⊂ (𝑈∩𝐴)∪(𝑈∩𝐵)

for all 𝑥 ∈ 𝑋.

To prove that the closure of the union of A and B is a subset of the union of the closures of A and B, we need to show that:

(𝐴∪𝐵)¯ ⊆ 𝐴¯∪𝐵¯

Let x be an arbitrary element in (𝐴∪𝐵)¯. We want to show that x ∈ 𝐴¯∪𝐵¯.

Recall that x is in the closure of a set if and only if every open neighborhood U of x intersects the set. In other words, x ∈ (𝐴∪𝐵)¯ if and only if for every open set U containing x, U ∩ (𝐴∪𝐵) ≠ ∅.

Now, let U be an open set containing x. Since U ∩ (𝐴∪𝐵) ≠ ∅, there exists an element y ∈ U such that y ∈ 𝐴∪𝐵. This means that y ∈ 𝐴 or y ∈ 𝐵. 

If y ∈ 𝐴, then U ∩ 𝐴 ≠ ∅, which implies that x ∈ 𝐴¯, since this holds for every open set U containing x. Similarly, if y ∈ 𝐵, then U ∩ 𝐵 ≠ ∅, which implies that x ∈ 𝐵¯. In either case, x ∈ 𝐴¯∪𝐵¯.

Since x was an arbitrary element in (𝐴∪𝐵)¯, we have shown that (𝐴∪𝐵)¯ ⊆ 𝐴¯∪𝐵¯.

Now, let's prove the other direction. We want to show that if there exists an open set U containing x such that 𝑈∩(𝐴∪𝐵) ⊂ (𝑈∩𝐴)∪(𝑈∩𝐵) for all 𝑥 ∈ 𝑋, then (𝐴∪𝐵)¯ ⊆ 𝐴¯∪𝐵¯.

Let x be an arbitrary element in 𝑋. If x ∈ 𝐴¯∪𝐵¯, then x ∈ 𝐴¯ or x ∈ 𝐵¯. If x ∈ 𝐴¯, then for every open set U containing x, U ∩ 𝐴 ≠ ∅. Similarly, if x ∈ 𝐵¯, then for every open set U containing x, U ∩ 𝐵 ≠ ∅. In either case, U ∩ (𝐴∪𝐵) ≠ ∅, which implies that x ∈ (𝐴∪𝐵)¯.

Since x was an arbitrary element in 𝑋, we have shown that if there exists an open set U containing x such that 𝑈∩(𝐴∪𝐵) ⊂ (𝑈∩𝐴)∪(𝑈∩𝐵) for all 𝑥 ∈ 𝑋, then (𝐴∪𝐵)¯ ⊆ 𝐴¯∪𝐵¯.

Thus, we have proved that the closure of the union of A and B is a subset of the union of the closures of A and B.
